elements.content: Three iridium­(III)-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), namely [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DMF)2(H2O)4]·6H2O·2DMF (1), [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DMA)2(H2O)2]·0.5H2O·2DMA (2), and [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DEF)2(H2O)2]·8H2O·2DEF (3) (ppy-COOH = methyl-3-(pyridin-2-yl)­benzoic acid, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide, DEF = N,N-diethylformamide), have been synthesized and characterized. Single-crystal structural determinations reveal that compounds 1–3 are isostructural, showing a three-dimensional framework structure with (3,6) connected rtl topologyin whose trimers of {Cd3(COO)6} are cross-linked by Ir­(ppy-COO)3 3–. The structures are completely different from those of other Ir­(III)-based MOFs. Compound 1 was selected for a detailed study on sensing properties. The excellent luminescence as well as good water stability of 1 makes it a highly selective and sensitive multiresponsive luminescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2–. The detection limits are 67.8 and 145.1 ppb, respectively. Compound 1 can also be used as an optical sensor for selective sensing of adenosine triphosphate (ATP2–) over adenosine diphosphate (ADP2–) and adenosine monophosphate (AMP2–) in aqueous solution. This is the first example of iridium­(III)-based MOFs for the optical detection of Fe3+, Cr2O7 2–, and ATP2–. More interestingly, the luminescent composite film doped with 1% (w/w) of compound 1, 1@PMMA (PMMA = poly­(methyl methacrylate)), can be successfully prepared, which endows efficient sensitivity for Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– detection and thus provides great potential for future applications.

Single-crystal structural determinations reveal that compounds 1-3 are isostructural, showing a three-dimensional framework structure with (3,6) connected rtl topologyin whose trimers of {Cd3(COO)6} are cross-linked by Ir(ppy-COO)3 3-. elements.content: The iridium­(III)-based metal−organic frameworks [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DMF)2(H2O)4]·6H2O·2DMF (1) (ppy-COOH = methyl-3-(pyridin-2-yl)­benzoic acid, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) can serve as a multiresponsive, highly sensitive luminescent sensor to detect Fe3+, Cr2O7 2−, and ATP2− in an aqueous media. The efficient sensing ability toward Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2− ions is retained in poly­(methyl methacrylate) film doped with a 1% concentration of compound 1.

The efficient sensing ability toward Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- ions is retained in poly(methyl methacrylate) film doped with a 1% concentration of compound 1.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline materials composed of organic linkers and secondary building units. Due to their well-defined structures and tunable porosities, a great number of innovative MOFs have been extensively studied for potential applications in numerous areas, including but not limited to gas storage and separation, sensing, ionic conductivity, catalysis, and other functional materials. In this regard, luminescent MOFs acting as optical sensors have attracted much interest on account of their obvious advantages of high sensitivity, low cost, and facile manipulation. In previous studies, the luminous property of MOFs has been shown to typically originate from organic ligands or lanthanide-based emissions (such as Eu3+ or Tb3+). Recently, great efforts have been made to improve the fluorescence or phosphorescence properties of MOFs through employment of functional molecular building blocks of the frameworks. In this regard, metalloligands with efficient light harvesting and high quantum yield are the desired candidates for this strategy.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline materials composed of organic linkers and secondary building units. Due to their well-defined structures and tunable porosities, a great number of innovative MOFs have been extensively studied for potential applications in numerous areas, including but not limited to gas storage and separation, sensing, ionic conductivity, catalysis, and other functional materials. In this regard, luminescent MOFs acting as optical sensors have attracted much interest on account of their obvious advantages of high sensitivity, low cost, and facile manipulation. In previous studies, the luminous property of MOFs has been shown to typically originate from organic ligands or lanthanide-based emissions (such as Eu3+ or Tb3+). Recently, great efforts have been made to improve the fluorescence or phosphorescence properties of MOFs through employment of functional molecular building blocks of the frameworks. In this regard, metalloligands with efficient light harvesting and high quantum yield are the desired candidates for this strategy.

elements.content: The luminescent iridium complexes have gained great attention owing to their high quantum efficiency, tunable emission energy, and long lifetime. The highly efficient emission is attributed to strong spin–orbit coupling of the Ir3+ ion with a 5d configuration, which leads to an efficient intersystem crossing of the singlet to the triplet excited state. The triplet metal to ligand charge transfer (3MLCT) results in the phosphorescence. The long-lived phosphorescence and high quantum yield of the iridium complexes, especially Ir­(ppy)3 (ppy = 2-phenylpyridine) and its derivatives, give them distinct advantages for applications in organic light-emitting diodes, chemosensors, bioimaging, and photocatalysis. In contrast, MOFs containing iridium complexes as linkers are extremely rare, and only a handful of them have been used as luminescent sensors to detect gas or vapors. The first example of this kind is [Zn4(μ4-O)­{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2] (ppy-COOH = 3-(pyridin-2-yl)­benzoic acid) (abbreviated as ZnIr-MOF), which shows a two-dimensional bilayer structure and can act as an effective sensor for O2. By use of Ir­(ppy)2(L) (L = organic dicarboxylate), a few luminescent MOFs were also obtained, and their selective detection of nitroaromatic explosives or organic solvents was explored.
elements.clean_text: The luminescent iridium complexes have gained great attention owing to their high quantum efficiency, tunable emission energy, and long lifetime. The highly efficient emission is attributed to strong spin-orbit coupling of the Ir3+ ion with a 5d configuration, which leads to an efficient intersystem crossing of the singlet to the triplet excited state. The triplet metal to ligand charge transfer (3MLCT) results in the phosphorescence. The long-lived phosphorescence and high quantum yield of the iridium complexes, especially Ir(ppy)3 (ppy = 2-phenylpyridine) and its derivatives, give them distinct advantages for applications in organic light-emitting diodes, chemosensors, bioimaging, and photocatalysis. In contrast, MOFs containing iridium complexes as linkers are extremely rare, and only a handful of them have been used as luminescent sensors to detect gas or vapors. The first example of this kind is [Zn4(μ4-O){Ir(ppy-COO)3}2] (ppy-COOH = 3-(pyridin-2-yl)benzoic acid) (abbreviated as ZnIr-MOF), which shows a two-dimensional bilayer structure and can act as an effective sensor for O2. By use of Ir(ppy)2(L) (L = organic dicarboxylate), a few luminescent MOFs were also obtained, and their selective detection of nitroaromatic explosives or organic solvents was explored.

elements.content: Selective sensing of ions and small biomolecules is very important in the life and environmental sciences. Much attention has been paid to the detection of ferric (Fe3+) and hexavalent chromium (Cr2O7 2–, CrO4 2–) ions. The Fe3+ ion influences electron transfer and oxygen metabolism processes in DNA and RNA synthesis. Both excess and deficiency from the normal permissible limit can induce serious disorders. Meanwhile, hexavalent chromium ions are potent carcinogens, which can cause serious damage to human health and the environment. On the other hand, great efforts have also been devoted to the selective detection of nucleoside phosphates such as adenosine triphosphate (ATP), adenosine diphosphate (ADP), and adenosine monophosphate (AMP), which play key roles in many cellular functions: for example, DNA synthesis, cell signaling, and membrane transport. Although a few luminescent MOFs have been developed in recent years to efficiently sense Fe3+, Cr2O7 2–, and ATP2–, those using iridium­(III)-based MOFs have never been described.
elements.clean_text: Selective sensing of ions and small biomolecules is very important in the life and environmental sciences. Much attention has been paid to the detection of ferric (Fe3+) and hexavalent chromium (Cr2O7 2-, CrO4 2-) ions. The Fe3+ ion influences electron transfer and oxygen metabolism processes in DNA and RNA synthesis. Both excess and deficiency from the normal permissible limit can induce serious disorders. Meanwhile, hexavalent chromium ions are potent carcinogens, which can cause serious damage to human health and the environment. On the other hand, great efforts have also been devoted to the selective detection of nucleoside phosphates such as adenosine triphosphate (ATP), adenosine diphosphate (ADP), and adenosine monophosphate (AMP), which play key roles in many cellular functions: for example, DNA synthesis, cell signaling, and membrane transport. Although a few luminescent MOFs have been developed in recent years to efficiently sense Fe3+, Cr2O7 2-, and ATP2-, those using iridium(III)-based MOFs have never been described.

elements.content: Herein we report for the first time that iridium­(III)-based MOFs can serve as multiresponsive selective sensors to detect Fe3+, Cr2O7 2–, and ATP2– in aqueous media. Three new compounds with the formulas [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DMF)2(H2O)4]·6H2O·2DMF (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) (1), [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DMA)2(H2O)2]·0.5H2O·2DMA (DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide) (2), and [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DEF)2(H2O)2]·8H2O·2DEF (DEF = N,N-diethylformamide) (3) have been obtained via solvothermal reactions (). The compounds are isostructural and show a new type of three-dimensional open framework structure among the Ir­(III)-based MOFs. Compound 1 is chosen as a representative to detect a series of metal ions and anions as well as nucleoside phosphates by taking the advantage of its excellent luminescence and good water stability. The results demonstrate that compound 1 is an efficient multiresponsive sensor for optical detection of Fe3+, Cr2O7 2–, and ATP2– in aqueous media. More interestingly, its sensing ability toward Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– ions remains in a poly­(methylmethacrylate) (PMMA) polymer film doped with a 1% concentration of compound 1, which could pave the way for future applications.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Routes for Compounds 1-3

elements.content: Methyl 3-(pyridin-2-yl)­benzoate (ppy-COOMe), [Ir­(ppy-COOMe)2(μ-Cl)]2, Ir­(ppy-COOMe)3, and Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 were prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were of reagent grade quality and were obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα) at room temperature. Infrared spectra were measured as KBr pellets on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in nitrogen in the temperature range 25–500 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min on a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1 instrument. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were determined with a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. Adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured using a BELSORP-max instrument (BEL Japan, Inc.). The UV–vis absorption and luminescence spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 UV/vis/NIR spectrometer and a PerkinElmer LS55 fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature, respectively. The emission lifetime in the solid state was determined on a Horiba Scientific FL3-1iHR1 spectrometer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) experiments were performed on PE Optima 5300 DV.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

Methyl 3-(pyridin-2-yl)benzoate (ppy-COOMe), [Ir(ppy-COOMe)2(μ-Cl)]2, Ir(ppy-COOMe)3, and Ir(ppy-COOH)3 were prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were of reagent grade quality and were obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα) at room temperature. Infrared spectra were measured as KBr pellets on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in nitrogen in the temperature range 25-500 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min on a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1 instrument. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were determined with a PerkinElmer 240C elemental analyzer. Adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured using a BELSORP-max instrument (BEL Japan, Inc.). The UV-vis absorption and luminescence spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 UV/vis/NIR spectrometer and a PerkinElmer LS55 fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature, respectively. The emission lifetime in the solid state was determined on a Horiba Scientific FL3-1iHR1 spectrometer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) experiments were performed on PE Optima 5300 DV.

elements.content: Compound 1 was obtained by a solvothermal reaction of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.1 mmol, 30.8 mg) and Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 (0.045 mmol, 34.6 mg) in a solution mixture of 12 mL of DMF and 4 mL of water at 100 °C. After 24 h, the solution was cooled to room temperature and orange hexagonal-plate-shaped crystals were obtained. Anal. Calcd for C84H90Cd3Ir2N10O26: C, 42.43; H, 3.81; N, 5.89. Found: C, 42.81; H, 3.98; N, 5.92. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3435 (s), 1656 (m), 1589 (s), 1556 (s), 1508 (m), 1475 (m), 1456 (m), 1407 (s), 1375 (s), 1315 (m), 1271 (m), 1226 (m), 1056 (m), 1028 (m), 779 (s).

elements.content: PMMA was doped with 1 powder in a proportion of 1% (w/w). The PMMA powder (500 mg) was dissolved in 5 mL of DMF, followed by the addition of the required amount of 1 (5 mg) in DMF, and the resulting mixture was heated at 35 °C for 60 min. The polymer film was obtained after evaporating the excess solvent at 40 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of 1@PMMA Film

PMMA was doped with 1 powder in a proportion of 1% (w/w). The PMMA powder (500 mg) was dissolved in 5 mL of DMF, followed by the addition of the required amount of 1 (5 mg) in DMF, and the resulting mixture was heated at 35 °C for 60 min. The polymer film was obtained after evaporating the excess solvent at 40 °C.

elements.content: A suspension of compound 1 in water was prepared by dispersing 10 mg of 1 powder in 1000 mL of ultrapure water under ultrasonic agitation for 90 min. The final concentration was 10 mg L–1. To explore the ability of the luminescent probe for ion detection, 2 mL of the above suspension was put in a 1 cm × 1 cm quartz cell, different volumes of detection solution were sequentially added into the cell, and the luminescence intensity was monitored at ca. 515 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing Experiments

A suspension of compound 1 in water was prepared by dispersing 10 mg of 1 powder in 1000 mL of ultrapure water under ultrasonic agitation for 90 min. The final concentration was 10 mg L-1. To explore the ability of the luminescent probe for ion detection, 2 mL of the above suspension was put in a 1 cm × 1 cm quartz cell, different volumes of detection solution were sequentially added into the cell, and the luminescence intensity was monitored at ca. 515 nm.

elements.content: A 5 mg portion of powder 1 was dispersed in 5 mL of Fe3+, Cr2O7 2– , AMP2–, ADP2–, and ATP2– solution (1 and 10 mM, respectively) for 12 h. The suspension was then centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 5 min to collect the powder. After washing 10 times with ultrapure water, the resulting powder was kept at 40 °C for 12 h and then subjected to PXRD measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Sample Preparation for PXRD Studies

A 5 mg portion of powder 1 was dispersed in 5 mL of Fe3+, Cr2O7 2- , AMP2-, ADP2-, and ATP2- solution (1 and 10 mM, respectively) for 12 h. The suspension was then centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 5 min to collect the powder. After washing 10 times with ultrapure water, the resulting powder was kept at 40 °C for 12 h and then subjected to PXRD measurements.

elements.content: Single crystals of 1–3 were selected for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 123 K. The data were integrated using the Siemens SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector face plate. Absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using SHELXTL. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and were refined anisotropically. All H atoms were refined isotropically with the isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-hydrogen atoms to which they are bonded. Guest molecules in the pores were highly disordered and could not be modeled. To account for this electron density, the program SQUEEZE was employed for compound 2. The number of free solvent molecules was confirmed by thermal analyses. The crystallographic data of 1–3 as well as monomers Ir­(ppy-COOMe)3 and Ir­(ppy-COOH)3·DMF are given in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables S1–S5.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystals of 1-3 were selected for indexing and intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 123 K. The data were integrated using the Siemens SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector face plate. Absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F  2  by full-matrix least-squares using SHELXTL. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps and were refined anisotropically. All H atoms were refined isotropically with the isotropic vibration parameters related to the non-hydrogen atoms to which they are bonded. Guest molecules in the pores were highly disordered and could not be modeled. To account for this electron density, the program SQUEEZE was employed for compound 2. The number of free solvent molecules was confirmed by thermal analyses. The crystallographic data of 1-3 as well as monomers Ir(ppy-COOMe)3 and Ir(ppy-COOH)3⋅DMF are given in , and the selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables S1-S5.

Compounds 1–3 were obtained as yellow hexagonal crystals by solvothermal reactions of Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 and Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O in sol/H2O (sol = DMF, DMA, DEF) solution at 90–100 °C. According to the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and infrared (IR) measurements, these compounds are isostructural, which was further confirmed by single-crystal structure analyses (Figures S1 and S2 and ). Therefore, only the structure of compound 1 is described in detail. Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half Cd2+ ions, one Ir­(ppy-COO)3 3–, two coordinated water molecules, one coordinated DMF, and one lattice DMF molecule. Other lattice solvent molecules cannot be accurately determined due to the severe disorder. The total number of lattice solvent molecules in the molecular formula was confirmed on the basis of both elemental and thermal analyses (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

Compounds 1-3 were obtained as yellow hexagonal crystals by solvothermal reactions of Ir(ppy-COOH)3 and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O in sol/H2O (sol = DMF, DMA, DEF) solution at 90-100 °C. According to the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and infrared (IR) measurements, these compounds are isostructural, which was further confirmed by single-crystal structure analyses (Figures S1 and S2 and ). Therefore, only the structure of compound 1 is described in detail. Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half Cd2+ ions, one Ir(ppy-COO)3 3-, two coordinated water molecules, one coordinated DMF, and one lattice DMF molecule. Other lattice solvent molecules cannot be accurately determined due to the severe disorder. The total number of lattice solvent molecules in the molecular formula was confirmed on the basis of both elemental and thermal analyses (Figure S3).

elements.content: As shown in a, the metallo-ligand of Ir­(ppy-COO)3 3– within the framework structure exhibits geometrical parameters (Ir–C, 1.983(12)–2.013(11) Å; Ir–N, 2.126(10)–2.137(12) Å) similar to those for discrete Ir­(ppy-COOMe)3 (Ir–C, 2.014(3) Å; Ir–N, 2.137(3) Å) or Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 (Ir–C, 1.996(3) Å; Ir–N, 2.126(3) Å) complexes (Tables S1–S5 and Figures S4 and S5). Each Ir­(ppy-COO)3 3– chelates and/or bridges three Cd2+ ions via its six carboxylate oxygen atoms. Two crystallographically distinct Cd atoms are found, both of which have octahedral environments. The Cd1 lies on the special position (0.5, 0.5, 0), surrounded by four carboxylate oxygen atoms and two oxygen atoms from DMF (Cd–O, 2.249(9)–2.302(12) Å), while Cd2 is located at a general position with the six sites occupied by four carboxylate oxygen atoms and two water molecules (Cd–O, 2.218(8)–2.461(14) Å). The neighboring {CdO6} octahedra are connected by O–C–O units, forming a trimer of {Cd3(COO)6} (b). The Cd···Cd distance within the trimer is 4.051 Å. Each trimer is linked to six Ir­(ppy-COO)3 3– ligands, and each Ir­(ppy-COO)3 3– is connected by three {Cd3(COO)6} trimers. Consequently, a three-dimensional framework structure is constructed (c), which shows a (3,6) connected rtl topology (d). The framework structure contains a 1D channel along the b axis, where the lattice solvent molecules reside. When the van der Waals radii are accounted for, the size of the channel is estimated as ca. 2.5 × 5.0 Å2.

elements.content: The structures of compounds 2 and 3 are similar to that of 1. The main difference is that the DMF molecule coordinated to the Cd1 atom in compound 1 is replaced by DMA in 2 and DEF in 3, respectively. Meanwhile, only one coordination water molecule is found in the asymmetric unit of compounds 2 and 3, and thus the Cd2 atom becomes five-coordinated in these two cases. Such a coordination mode could be a consequence of steric hindrance of the coordinated DMA or DEF molecules, which contain more −CH3 groups in comparison to DMF. As shown clearly in Figures S6 and S7, the organic groups of the DMA and DEF molecules protrude out to the center of the channels and fill in the channel cavities.

Meanwhile, only one coordination water molecule is found in the asymmetric unit of compounds 2 and 3, and thus the Cd2 atom becomes five-coordinated in these two cases. Such a coordination mode could be a consequence of steric hindrance of the coordinated DMA or DEF molecules, which contain more -CH3 groups in comparison to DMF. As shown clearly in Figures S6 and S7, the organic groups of the DMA and DEF molecules protrude out to the center of the channels and fill in the channel cavities.

elements.content: It is worth mentioning that [Zn4(μ4-O)­{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2] (ZnIr-MOF) is the only known MOF-containing Ir­(ppy-COO)3 3– metallo ligand so far. It shows a two-dimensional layer structure in which the Zn4(μ4-O) nodes are connected by Ir­(ppy-COO)3 3– linkers. Therefore, compounds 1–3 are the second examples of MOFs containing Ir­(ppy-COO)3 3– linkers and provide an entirely new type of structure among the iridium­(III)-based MOFs. A detailed investigation on the gas sorption and ion detection has been performed for compound 1 as a representative.
elements.clean_text: It is worth mentioning that [Zn4(μ4-O){Ir(ppy-COO)3}2] (ZnIr-MOF) is the only known MOF-containing Ir(ppy-COO)3 3- metallo ligand so far. It shows a two-dimensional layer structure in which the Zn4(μ4-O) nodes are connected by Ir(ppy-COO)3 3- linkers. Therefore, compounds 1-3 are the second examples of MOFs containing Ir(ppy-COO)3 3- linkers and provide an entirely new type of structure among the iridium(III)-based MOFs. A detailed investigation on the gas sorption and ion detection has been performed for compound 1 as a representative.

elements.content: Before the gas sorption isotherms measurement, compound 1 was activated at 100 °C under vacuum for 2 h. The PXRD pattern of the activated sample is identical with that simulated from the single-crystal data (), suggesting that the framework structure of 1 is maintained after activation. As shown in , the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm at 77 K shows a type I curve, which is typical for microporous materials. The Langmuir surface area is 194.6 m2 g–1. The pore size distribution determined by the Horvath–Kawazoe (HK) method is 0.54 nm for 1 (, inset), close to that found for ZnIr-MOF (0.51 nm). The total pore volume is 0.089 cm3/g, which is slightly larger than the calculated value (0.076 cm3/g), attributed to the partial loss of the coordinated water molecules during the thermal activation process.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Isotherms

Before the gas sorption isotherms measurement, compound 1 was activated at 100 °C under vacuum for 2 h. The PXRD pattern of the activated sample is identical with that simulated from the single-crystal data (), suggesting that the framework structure of 1 is maintained after activation. As shown in , the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm at 77 K shows a type I curve, which is typical for microporous materials. The Langmuir surface area is 194.6 m2 g-1. The pore size distribution determined by the Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) method is 0.54 nm for 1 (, inset), close to that found for ZnIr-MOF (0.51 nm). The total pore volume is 0.089 cm3/g, which is slightly larger than the calculated value (0.076 cm3/g), attributed to the partial loss of the coordinated water molecules during the thermal activation process.

elements.content: The CO2 adsorption and desorption isotherms were also measured at 273 and 298 K (Figure S8). The maximum CO2 uptakes at 100 kPa are 18.86 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 11.9 cm3 g–1 at 298 K, respectively. The adsorption enthalpy (Q st) of CO2 at low coverage was calculated to be 31.2 kJ mol–1 and remains steady at 26–28 kJ mol–1 throughout the adsorption process (Figure S9). Clearly, the Q st value of 1 for CO2 is much higher than that of ZnIr-MOF (21.8 kJ mol–1), attributed to the interactions between CO2 and exposed Cd sites in the framework host after thermal activation.

elements.content: a shows the solid state UV–vis absorption spectra of both compound 1 and metallo-ligand Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 at room temperature, translated from the diffuse reflectance spectra by the Kubelka–Munk equation: F(R) = (1 – R)2/2R. The high-energy bands (<340 nm) are assigned to spin-allowed 1π–π* transitions localized on the ligand of ppy-COOH. The lower energy absorptions (ca. 340–500 nm) are attributed to spin-allowed singlet metal to ligand charge-transfer (1MLCT) transitions.

Optical Properties

 a shows the solid state UV-vis absorption spectra of both compound 1 and metallo-ligand Ir(ppy-COOH)3 at room temperature, translated from the diffuse reflectance spectra by the Kubelka-Munk equation: F(R) = (1 - R)2/2R. The high-energy bands (<340 nm) are assigned to spin-allowed 1π-π* transitions localized on the ligand of ppy-COOH. The lower energy absorptions (ca. 340-500 nm) are attributed to spin-allowed singlet metal to ligand charge-transfer (1MLCT) transitions.

elements.content: (a) UV–vis absorption spectra and (b) emission spectra of 1 and Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 in the solid state (λex 380 nm).
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) UV-vis absorption spectra and (b) emission spectra of 1 and Ir(ppy-COOH)3 in the solid state (λex 380 nm).

elements.content: In comparison with Ir­(ppy-COOH)3, however, the absorption edge of 1 is red-shifted, attributed to the charge transfer from the metallo ligand to {Cd3(COO)6} cluster. A red shift is also observed in the solid-state photoluminescence emission spectrum of compound 1 (λex 380 nm), which shows a peak at ca. 519 nm in comparison with two maxima at ca. 488 and 510 nm for Ir­(ppy-COOH)3, corresponding to the 3MLCT transition (b). The tiny red shift relative to Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 may be attributed to the coordination of metallo-ligands with the electron-withdrawing Cd2+ centers, which enhances the rigidity of the ligands and decreases the LUMO energy. The phosphorescence lifetime of 1 (2.95 μs) is much longer than that of the parent linker (1.93 μs) (Figure S10).

A red shift is also observed in the solid-state photoluminescence emission spectrum of compound 1 (λex 380 nm), which shows a peak at ca. 519 nm in comparison with two maxima at ca. 488 and 510 nm for Ir(ppy-COOH)3, corresponding to the 3MLCT transition (b). The tiny red shift relative to Ir(ppy-COOH)3 may be attributed to the coordination of metallo-ligands with the electron-withdrawing Cd2+ centers, which enhances the rigidity of the ligands and decreases the LUMO energy. The phosphorescence lifetime of 1 (2.95 μs) is much longer than that of the parent linker (1.93 μs) (Figure S10).

elements.content: Notably, compound 1 is stable after immersion in water for 2 months. It is also stable after ultrasonic treatment of the ground powder in water for 1.5 h, as confirmed by the PXRD patterns ( and Figure S12). The ICP measurements revealed that the dissolution of compound 1 in water was less than 2.4% within 7 days (Table S6). The phosphorescence properties of 1 suspended in aqueous solution have also been investigated, which possesses a stable phosphorescence emission with a maximum appearing at ca. 515 nm.
elements.clean_text: Notably, compound 1 is stable after immersion in water for 2 months. It is also stable after ultrasonic treatment of the ground powder in water for 1.5 h, as confirmed by the PXRD patterns ( and Figure S12). The ICP measurements revealed that the dissolution of compound 1 in water was less than 2.4% within 7 days (Table S6). The phosphorescence properties of 1 suspended in aqueous solution have also been investigated, which possesses a stable phosphorescence emission with a maximum appearing at ca. 515 nm.

elements.content: The relatively strong phosphorescence emission intensity and the high stability of 1 suspended in water make it a potential luminescent sensor for cations and anions. The measurements were performed using 2 mL of the suspension of 1 in water with a concentration of 10 mg L–1. Aqueous solutions of Na+, Mg2+, K+, Ca2+, Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ (each with concentration 10 mM) were prepared from chloride salts. The Fe2+ solution was prepared from ferrous chloride and used immediately. The luminescence intensities of 1 in response to various cations in aqueous solutions (30 μL, 10 mM) are shown in Figure S13 and a. Obviously, most cations display a negligible influence on or only minor interferences with the emission intensity. The most significant observation is that the bright yellow-green emission of 1 was completely quenched in the presence of Fe3+ ion, indicating that compound 1 can be an efficient sensor for Fe3+ ion detection in aqueous solution. To investigate the selectivity of Fe3+ over the other metal ions, anti-interference sensing experiments were conducted in the coexistence of other metal ions. The quenching efficiency was found not to be affected by any other metal ions (Figures S14 and S15). The results demonstrate that compound 1 can be a promising luminescent probe for detecting Fe3+ even in the presence of other interfering metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Ions

The relatively strong phosphorescence emission intensity and the high stability of 1 suspended in water make it a potential luminescent sensor for cations and anions. The measurements were performed using 2 mL of the suspension of 1 in water with a concentration of 10 mg L-1. Aqueous solutions of Na+, Mg2+, K+, Ca2+, Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ (each with concentration 10 mM) were prepared from chloride salts. The Fe2+ solution was prepared from ferrous chloride and used immediately. The luminescence intensities of 1 in response to various cations in aqueous solutions (30 μL, 10 mM) are shown in Figure S13 and a. Obviously, most cations display a negligible influence on or only minor interferences with the emission intensity. The most significant observation is that the bright yellow-green emission of 1 was completely quenched in the presence of Fe3+ ion, indicating that compound 1 can be an efficient sensor for Fe3+ ion detection in aqueous solution. To investigate the selectivity of Fe3+ over the other metal ions, anti-interference sensing experiments were conducted in the coexistence of other metal ions. The quenching efficiency was found not to be affected by any other metal ions (Figures S14 and S15). The results demonstrate that compound 1 can be a promising luminescent probe for detecting Fe3+ even in the presence of other interfering metal ions.

elements.content: In an effort to check the sensitivity of 1 toward Fe3+ ion, concentration-dependent emission measurements were carried out. As shown in b, the phosphorescence intensities gradually decreased with increasing concentration of Fe3+ ions. The initial phosphorescence intensity of 1 was decreased by 99.5% when only 8.37 ppm Fe3+ was added. Further, the quenching efficiency can be rationalized by the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation, I 0/I = K SV[M] + 1, where I 0 and I are the relative phosphorescence intensities before and after incorporation of the analyte, [M] is the molar concentration of the Fe3+ ion, and K SV (M–1) is the Stern–Volmer quenching constant. As illustrated in c, the SV quenching curve for Fe3+ shows a good linear relationship at low concentration (2.5–40 μM) with a linear fit correlation coefficient of 0.9945. The K SV value is calculated as 1.165 × 104 M–1, suggesting a strong quenching effect on phosphorescence. The detection limit is 67.8 ppb (Figure S16 and Table S7), which is comparable to or better than those obtained by other luminescent sensors for Fe3+ (Tables S8 and S9). However, an increase in concentration (≥50 μM) leads to the deviation of the curve from a straight line, indicating the coexistence of both static and dynamic mechanisms in the quenching process.

elements.content: Simultaneously, sensing properties of 1 toward various anions such as F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, BrO3 –, IO3 –, NO3 –, CO3 2–, SO4 2–, PF6 –, HPO4 2–, and Cr2O7 2– as their potassium salts were also tested by photoluminescence spectra. d and Figures S17–S19 clearly show that a selective quenching response was detected only in the case of Cr2O7 2–, whereas the other anions have no discernible effect. The emission intensity of 1 decreased continuously with an increasing concentration of Cr2O7 2– (e). Interestingly, the quenched intensity (I 0/I) of 1 has a good linear relationship (R 2 = 0.991) over the whole measured concentration range (5–150 μM), indicating that only one type of quenching mechanism is involved in this process. The K SV value is calculated to be 3.475 × 104 M–1, comparable to those of other well-designed Cr2O7 2– fluorescent sensors (Tables S8 and S9). The anti-interference experiments demonstrate that Cr2O7 2– can be solely detected by 1 through the phosphorescence quenching process (Figures S18 and S19). The results suggest that compound 1 can be a highly selective and sensitive detector for Cr2O7 2– in water. The detection limit is 145.1 ppb (Figure S20 and Table S7). It is worth mentioning that most of the known MOF-based sensors of Fe3+ and/or Cr2O7 2– have been exploited in organic solvents such as DMF because of their poor stabilities in water.

elements.content: The response capacity is certainly an important result, but the possible sensing mechanism of phosphorescence quenching by Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– must be determined by further analysis. According to previous reports, luminescence quenching of MOFs by ions mainly originates from four possible approaches: (1) the strong interaction between ions and the frameworks, (2) ion exchange with the targeted analyte, (3) the collapse of the main framework structure by ions, (4) competitive absorption of excitation energy by ions, fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET), and other excited-state processes.

According to previous reports, luminescence quenching of MOFs by ions mainly originates from four possible approaches: (1) the strong interaction between ions and the frameworks, (2) ion exchange with the targeted analyte, (3) the collapse of the main framework structure by ions, (4) competitive absorption of excitation energy by ions, fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET), and other excited-state processes.

elements.content: Considering that compound 1 contains pores of size 0.54 nm, the Fe3+ ions could easily enter into the pores of 1 upon dispersion in water. Therefore, the interaction between Fe3+ ions and framework of 1 as well as the ion exchange between Fe3+ and Cd2+ ions cannot be excluded. This speculation is supported by the PXRD measurements and IR spectra. Although the framework structure could be retained after immersing 5 mg of compound 1 in 5 mL of Fe3+ solution of concentration 1 or 10 mM for 12 h, an additional peak appears at 2θ = 7.86° ( and Figure S21). The IR spectra measurements suggest that compound 1 is stable after soaking in a lower concentration (1 mM) of Fe3+ solution. However, after immersion in a higher concentration (10 mM) of Fe3+ solution, an obvious blue shift in IR absorption from 1656 to 1687 cm–1 occurs for the CO bonds, indicating slight structural damage (Figures S22 and S23). This may explain the abrupt increase in I 0/I in c when the concentration of Fe3+ ion is above 100 μM. Notably, ion exchange is usually a slow process that takes a long balance time to completely quench the luminescence. In the present case, the phosphorescent moiety of Ir­(ppy-COO)3 remains even if the ion exchange occurs and/or the framework structure collapses; the quick phosphorescence quenching in the presence of Fe3+ ion could be mainly due to the competitive absorption of excitation energy by Fe3+ ion. For Cr2O7 2– anion detection, the interaction between the anion and framework of 1 could be largely excluded because of the large size of the anion. Therefore, the competitive absorption of excitation energy by the Cr2O7 2– anion could play a key role.

elements.content: In order to prove our hypothesis, the UV–vis absorption spectra of each cation and anion in aqueous solution were recorded, as shown in Figures S24 and S25. Both Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– solutions show obvious absorptions in the range 300–400 nm, but solutions of the other cations or anions do not. This means that the excitation wavelength of compound 1 is totally overlapped by the absorption spectra of Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– ions. The result demonstrates that transfer of the excitation energy to the emissive center is effectively suppressed by Fe3+ or Cr2O7 2– ions. It is well-known that a FRET process can also lead to luminescence quenching. However, this mechanism is excluded here because of an inappreciable spectral overlap between the absorption spectrum of Fe3+ or Cr2O7 2– aqueous solution and the emission peaks of compound 1. Thus, the quenching mechanism due to competitive absorption of excitation energy by ions is operative in both cases, as described in a few other systems. For the Fe3+ detection process, the mechanism involving an Fe3+–framework interaction and/or Fe3+–Cd2+ exchange cannot be excluded.

elements.content: The competitive absorption of excitation energy by ions could also occur when the metallo-ligand of Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 is used as the sensor. Indeed, a progressive phosphorescence quenching of Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 suspended in water was observed upon addition of Fe3+ or Cr2O7 2– ions (Figures S26–S29). In comparison with those of compound 1, however, the quenching constant (K SV) of the ligand is smaller and the detection limit becomes larger (Table S10). The results indicate that the response time and the sensitivity of Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 could be improved by incorporating this ligand into the framework structure of 1.

elements.content: To explore the potential application of compound 1 in the detection of nucleotide, phosphorescence quenching titrations were performed by gradual addition of nucleotide phosphates such as adenosine triphosphate (ATP2–), adenosine diphosphate (ADP2–) and adenosine monophosphate (AMP2–). As shown in , a significant phosphorescence quenching was observed upon incremental addition of ATP2–, unlike the cases of ADP2– and AMP2–, which scarcely induced phosphorescence quenching of 1 under the same range of concentrations. Moreover, the degree of quenching is dependent on the concentration of ATP2–. When the concentration was low (0.1–0.3 mM), both the emission peak (at 514 nm) and intensity remained almost unchanged. Once the concentration of ATP2– was above 0.4 mM, a blue shift of the emission peak to ca. 502 nm was observed, accompanied by a reduction of the intensity. These results clearly indicate the high selectivity of 1 toward ATP2–. The plot of quenched intensity versus the concentration of ATP2– can be fit by a first-order exponential function, indicating that the quenching process could be diffusion-controlled (Figure S30).
elements.clean_text:
Detection of ATP2- 

To explore the potential application of compound 1 in the detection of nucleotide, phosphorescence quenching titrations were performed by gradual addition of nucleotide phosphates such as adenosine triphosphate (ATP2-), adenosine diphosphate (ADP2-) and adenosine monophosphate (AMP2-). As shown in , a significant phosphorescence quenching was observed upon incremental addition of ATP2-, unlike the cases of ADP2- and AMP2-, which scarcely induced phosphorescence quenching of 1 under the same range of concentrations. Moreover, the degree of quenching is dependent on the concentration of ATP2-. When the concentration was low (0.1-0.3 mM), both the emission peak (at 514 nm) and intensity remained almost unchanged. Once the concentration of ATP2- was above 0.4 mM, a blue shift of the emission peak to ca. 502 nm was observed, accompanied by a reduction of the intensity. These results clearly indicate the high selectivity of 1 toward ATP2-. The plot of quenched intensity versus the concentration of ATP2- can be fit by a first-order exponential function, indicating that the quenching process could be diffusion-controlled (Figure S30).

elements.content: The selective sensing ability of compound 1 toward ATP2– over ADP2– and AMP2– is unexpected. In order to analyze the possible mechanism of phosphorescence quenching by ATP2–, we measured the absorption spectra of the aqueous solutions of ATP2–, ADP2–, and AMP2–(1 mM). All exhibit identical absorption properties and show no absorptions above 300 nm (Figure S31). Therefore, the mechanism of competitive absorption of excitation energy by ions can be ruled out, unlike in the cases of Fe3+ or Cr2O7 2–. To check whether the structure of 1 is collapsed upon exposure to ATP2–, the PXRD measurements were conducted for the sample before and after immersion in ATP2– solution (10 mM) for 12 h. Interestingly, the ATP2–-treated sample shows only two broad peaks at ca. 7.6 and 12.6°, indicating an amorphous phase (Figure S21). In contrast, the PXRD patterns for the ADP2–- or AMP2–-treated samples remain similar to that for the pristine sample of 1. Meanwhile, the coordinated carboxylic groups in the ATP2–-treated sample demonstrated an obvious blue shift (from 1656 to 1674 cm–1) (Figure S23). All of these results suggest that an interaction between ATP2– and compound 1 could occur, leading to the collapse of the framework structure, thereby resulting in the phosphorescence quenching. The collapse of the framework could be caused by the ATP2– and framework interaction at lower pH, considering that the pH of ATP2– solution is lower than those of ADP2– and AMP2– solutions (Figure S32). Indeed, the phosphorescence lifetime of compound 1 after ATP2– addition is 1.86 μs, which is much shorter than that of the pristine compound (2.95 μs) but closer to that of the ligand (1.93 μs) (Figure S33). Further work demonstrates that selective phosphorescence quenching toward ATP2– over ADP2– and AMP2– also occurs for the ligand Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 suspended in water, but only after the addition of 0.8 mM ATP2– (Figures S34–S36). We also checked the pH dependence of the phosphorescence of the ligand, but no significant quenching was observed (Figure S37). Obviously, it must be the interaction between ATP2– and Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 or Ir­(ppy-COO)3 moieties that leads to the phosphorescence quenching. The underlying mechanism is, however, still not clear to us. Nevertheless, since fluorescent probes for ATP2– over ADP2– and AMP2– have rarely been found in the literature, this work provides a new way for selective detection of nucleotide by MOFs.

elements.content: For practical applications, it is of vital importance to realize materials with low cost that are reusable many times. One facile and efficient route along this line is to dope the functional MOF materials into suitable polymers. Thus 1% (w/w) of compound 1 was doped in polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) in DMF, forming a composite film denoted as 1@PMMA. Thermal analysis reveals that 1@PMMA is stable without any weight loss until 110 °C. A major weight loss occurs from 120 to 400 °C, corresponding to the burning of the organic components (Figure S38). To check whether the framework structure is retained in the composite, we prepared the sample doped with 5% (w/w) of compound 1. The PXRD pattern of sample 5% 1@PMMA matches well with that of the pristine compound, although that of 1% 1@PMMA shows only two very broad peaks due to the low content of compound 1 (Figures S39 and S40).
elements.clean_text:
1@PMMA Film as Sensor

For practical applications, it is of vital importance to realize materials with low cost that are reusable many times. One facile and efficient route along this line is to dope the functional MOF materials into suitable polymers. Thus 1% (w/w) of compound 1 was doped in polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) in DMF, forming a composite film denoted as 1@PMMA. Thermal analysis reveals that 1@PMMA is stable without any weight loss until 110 °C. A major weight loss occurs from 120 to 400 °C, corresponding to the burning of the organic components (Figure S38). To check whether the framework structure is retained in the composite, we prepared the sample doped with 5% (w/w) of compound 1. The PXRD pattern of sample 5% 1@PMMA matches well with that of the pristine compound, although that of 1% 1@PMMA shows only two very broad peaks due to the low content of compound 1 (Figures S39 and S40).

elements.content: The phosphorescence response of 1@PMMA film was also tested. The film was immersed in a series of different concentrations of Fe3+ or Cr2O7 2– aqueous solutions, and then the emission intensity change was measured. a shows the variation in the phosphorescence intensity of 1@PMMA in the presence of aqueous solutions of Fe3+. Apparently, the intensity decreases with increasing concentration of Fe3+ ions. The quenching constant K SV value is calculated as 2.24 × 103 M–1, which is 1 magnitude lower than that of pure 1 suspended in water, attributed to the reduction of interactions between the metal ion and framework structure in the composite. The Stern–Volmer quenching curve shows a good linear relationship within the full test concentration range, indicating that only one mechanism (e.g., competitive absorption) dominates in the quenching process. Remarkably, the response capability of 1@PMMA to Cr2O7 2– is even improved in comparison with pure 1 suspended in water, showing a slightly larger K sv value of 3.64 × 104 M–1. The detection limits were determined to be 277.9 ppb for Fe3+ and 169.5 ppb for Cr2O7 2– (Figures S41 and S42 and Table S11).

elements.content: When 1@PMMA film was separated from the aqueous solutions, no variation in the phosphorescence intensity was observed. After five iterations, the 1@PMMA film still retained superior responsiveness, demonstrating a good stability and reproducibility. Unfortunately, the composite film loses the ability to respond to ATP2– (Figure S43). This may be explained by the fact that the formation of a polymer composite improves the stability of 1, thereby preventing it from a strong interaction with ATP2– anion.

elements.content: We have successfully synthesized three iridium­(III)-containing Cd­(II)-organic frameworks, namely [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DMF)2(H2O)4]·6H2O·2DMF (1), [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DMA)2(H2O)2]·0.5H2O·2DMA (2), and [Cd3{Ir­(ppy-COO)3}2(DEF)2(H2O)2]·8H2O·2DEF (3), using Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 as the linker. Compounds 1–3 are isostructural and show a 3D open framework structure with a (3,6) connected rtl topology, which is completely different from the structures of the other Ir­(III)-based MOFs. An investigation of sensing properties using compound 1 as a representative reveals that compound 1 can serve as a luminescent sensor that exhibits instant and selective luminescence quenching properties toward Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– ions in aqueous media. Moreover, it is also a promising luminescent probe for selective sensing of ATP2– over ADP2– and AMP2– in aqueous solution. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of an iridium­(III)-based metal–organic framework as a multiresponsive luminescent sensor for Fe3+, Cr2O7 2–, and ATP2– in aqueous media. Furthermore, a composite of 1@PMMA containing 1% (w/w) of compound 1 in polymer shows not only improved thermal stability but also efficient sensitivity for Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2– detection. This convenient strategy provides the possibility for the application of luminescent Ir-based MOFs in optical sensing polymer films.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized three iridium(III)-containing Cd(II)-organic frameworks, namely [Cd3{Ir(ppy-COO)3}2(DMF)2(H2O)4]⋅6H2O⋅2DMF (1), [Cd3{Ir(ppy-COO)3}2(DMA)2(H2O)2]⋅0.5H2O⋅2DMA (2), and [Cd3{Ir(ppy-COO)3}2(DEF)2(H2O)2]⋅8H2O⋅2DEF (3), using Ir(ppy-COOH)3 as the linker. Compounds 1-3 are isostructural and show a 3D open framework structure with a (3,6) connected rtl topology, which is completely different from the structures of the other Ir(III)-based MOFs. An investigation of sensing properties using compound 1 as a representative reveals that compound 1 can serve as a luminescent sensor that exhibits instant and selective luminescence quenching properties toward Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- ions in aqueous media. Moreover, it is also a promising luminescent probe for selective sensing of ATP2- over ADP2- and AMP2- in aqueous solution. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of an iridium(III)-based metal-organic framework as a multiresponsive luminescent sensor for Fe3+, Cr2O7 2-, and ATP2- in aqueous media. Furthermore, a composite of 1@PMMA containing 1% (w/w) of compound 1 in polymer shows not only improved thermal stability but also efficient sensitivity for Fe3+ and Cr2O7 2- detection. This convenient strategy provides the possibility for the application of luminescent Ir-based MOFs in optical sensing polymer films.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 was obtained by a solvothermal reaction of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.1 mmol, 30.8 mg) and Ir­(ppy-COOH)3 (0.045 mmol, 34.6 mg) in a solution mixture of 12 mL of DMF and 4 mL of water at 100 °C. After 24 h, the solution was cooled to room temperature and orange hexagonal-plate-shaped crystals were obtained. Anal. Calcd for C84H90Cd3Ir2N10O26: C, 42.43; H, 3.81; N, 5.89. Found: C, 42.81; H, 3.98; N, 5.92. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3435 (s), 1656 (m), 1589 (s), 1556 (s), 1508 (m), 1475 (m), 1456 (m), 1407 (s), 1375 (s), 1315 (m), 1271 (m), 1226 (m), 1056 (m), 1028 (m), 779 (s).

Preparation of <bold>1@PMMA</bold> Film

PMMA was doped with 1 powder in a proportion of 1% (w/w). The PMMA powder (500 mg) was dissolved in 5 mL of DMF, followed by the addition of the required amount of 1 (5 mg) in DMF, and the resulting mixture was heated at 35 °C for 60 min. The polymer film was obtained after evaporating the excess solvent at 40 °C.

cln_elements.content:
Before the gas sorption isotherms measurement, compound 1 was activated at 100 °C under vacuum for 2 h. The PXRD pattern of the activated sample is identical with that simulated from the single-crystal data (), suggesting that the framework structure of 1 is maintained after activation. As shown in , the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm at 77 K shows a type I curve, which is typical for microporous materials. The Langmuir surface area is 194.6 m2 g–1. The pore size distribution determined by the Horvath–Kawazoe (HK) method is 0.54 nm for 1 (, inset), close to that found for ZnIr-MOF (0.51 nm). The total pore volume is 0.089 cm3/g, which is slightly larger than the calculated value (0.076 cm3/g), attributed to the partial loss of the coordinated water molecules during the thermal activation process.

<bold>1@PMMA</bold> Film as Sensor

For practical applications, it is of vital importance to realize materials with low cost that are reusable many times. One facile and efficient route along this line is to dope the functional MOF materials into suitable polymers. Thus 1% (w/w) of compound 1 was doped in polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) in DMF, forming a composite film denoted as 1@PMMA. Thermal analysis reveals that 1@PMMA is stable without any weight loss until 110 °C. A major weight loss occurs from 120 to 400 °C, corresponding to the burning of the organic components (Figure S38). To check whether the framework structure is retained in the composite, we prepared the sample doped with 5% (w/w) of compound 1. The PXRD pattern of sample 5% 1@PMMA matches well with that of the pristine compound, although that of 1% 1@PMMA shows only two very broad peaks due to the low content of compound 1 (Figures S39 and S40).

Iridium(III)-Based Metal–Organic Frameworks
as Multiresponsive Luminescent Sensors for Fe3+, Cr2O7
2–, and ATP2– in Aqueous Media
